The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

div.p: EEN VERCLARINGE Vande Officieren ende Compagnie van het Zee-Volck / oft Matroſen op Sijne Majeſteyes Schepen: Ghenoemt de Stantfaſtige Reformatie / de Gordine / de Swaluwe / de Anteloop / de Satisfactie / 't Hert / de Roebuck / de Croſſant oft Halve Maen / den Pellican / de Iouffrouw Morinne / voor deſes beſtelt tot Sijne Majeſteyts Dienſt. Meteen Aenlockinghe vande Reſte vande Vloot / ende derſelve Broederen / aen Landtzynde / om met hun te voegen in derſelve Gherechtich Voornemen.

p.hi: A DECLARATION Of the Officers and Company of Seamen aboard his Majeſties Shippes, the Conſtant Reformation, the Convertine, the Swallow, the Antelope, the Satisfaction, the Hynd, The Roebuck, the Creſcent, the Pellican, the Blackmore Lady, lately reſcued for his Majeſties ſervice: with an Invitation to the reſt of the fleet, and their Brethren on land, to joyne with them in their juſt undertakings.

div.head: Een Verclaringhe vande Officieren ende Compagnie van het Zee-Volck, oft Matroſen op Syne Majeſteyts Schepen; Ghenoemt de Standifaſtighe Reformatie, de Gordine, de Swaluwe, de Anteloop, de Satisfactie, 't Hert, de Roebuck, de Croiſſant oft Halve Maen, den Pellican, de Ioffrow Morinne, voor deſes beſtolt tot Syne Majeſteyts Dienst. Meteen aenlockinghe vande reste vande Vloot, ende derſelve Broederen, aen Landt zijnde, om met hun te voegen in derſelve gerechti • h voornemen.
div.p:
WY hebben overlang met groote patientie verwacht een geluckich eynde van onſe verderflijcke ſcheuringhe, door middel van een Perſonel-Tractaet, ſo menichmael op-ghedrongen, door onſe Broederen in Scotlandt, ende ernſtelijck begeert, vande Generaliteyt van het Coninckrijcke, als blijckt by de verſcheydene Petitien vande Reſpective Graeffchappen, oft Provintien, tot dien eynde onlanghs ghedaen: Maer wy bevinden by volle experiencie, dat de Independerende Partye, in plaets van d'appliceringhe van hun ſelven, tot het beſtellen ende veraccorderen der differentien, achtervolgens hun publijckelijck ghegeven, beloften aen het gantſche Conincrijcke (maer ſeer ſchandelijcken ghevioleert in haer Voor-ſtellinghen, in't Leger), hebben in hare Handen ghenomen, ende met Garniſoen beſet al de ſterke plaetſen van't Coninckrijck, over-loopende, ontwapenende ende plunderende het platte Landt, als oft het een gheconqueſteerdt Volck ware. Ende dit alles om geen ander oorſaecke, als dat het Volck in eene ootmoedighe maniere, haer begeerte om Vrede te hebben, gheopenbaert hadde, ende een eynde te hebben van deſe ſware verdruckinghen, die op hun laghen, door de arbitraire macht van Commiſſien ende de ongerechtighe continuatie vande Accyſen ende Land-ſchattinghen: Naer de gantſche verſtroyinghe van des Coninckx Legher, van welcker, boeten oft beſtraffinghen ende compoſitien, Sy gelts ghenoech kreghen, om voldaen te hebben het meeſte deel der ſchulden van het Coninckrijcke. Ende van ghelijcken ſiende dat
de Macht ende den Staet vande Scheeps-Vloot in ſodanige handen waren gheſtelt, die niet alleen Vyanden waren, vanden Coninck ende het Coninckrijck, maer oock vande Monarchie ſelfs: Dat den Styl vande Commiſſien ter See, was onlangs verandert, latende des Coninckx naem daer uyt, ende alleen het Parlament mentionerende ende het Legher. t' Welck wy verſtonden te zyn een ontervinghe van Sijne Majeſteyt ende Sijne Kinderen, dat wy geen beſtelde maniere en hadden van Gods Dienſt t▪Scheep, geen Avontmalen, weynich oft geen Predicatien in ghebruyck, als van ongeleerde ende mechanique Perſoonen, datter eenen aenſlach was om Lant-Soldaten op elck Schip te ſenden, om te vermeeſteren en de t' overtreffen de Zee-luyden, dingen ſo gants cōtrary de oude Gewoonten ende Orderen ter Zee, als dat wy, ons dachten in Conſcientie verbonden te zijn, om yets te doen tot weder-kryginghe von ons eygen Recht: De herſtellinge vande Religie, naer Gods Woort, ende het Verbont ſo ſolemnelijcken ghemaeckt. d'Eer, Behoudeniſſe ende Vryheyt van Sijne Majeſteyt: De Privilegie van 't Parlament: Ende de Vryheyt vande Onderdanen. Ende niet langher ghemaeckt te zijn het ongheluckige Inſtrument van d'ellenden vanden Coninck ende Coninckrijck, tot welcken tijdt God ons inden Sin gaf ende onſe herten encourage erden ende onſe handen ſterckten om Colonel Ramsborough af te ſetten van het Commandement vande Vloote. Een Man van heele verderffelijck beſtaen, beyde in Religie ende Policie ende een bekent Vyant vanden Vrede, ende van 't oude Gouvernement van dit Coninckrijck, 't welck wy gheſworen hebben te mainteneren ende te behouden, met ons Lyf ende Goederen. Begeerende alle eerlijcke Zee-luyden niet langer tot ſpot te zijn met woordē, maer u al tſamen tot ons te voeghen ende uwe handen te ſlaen aen ſo een eerlijck Werck, waer van de Eere (naeſt God) u ſal ghegheven werden, ende de Beloninghe buyten twyffel ſal naer advenant zijn, in deſe Wereelt ende inde toekomende. Wy zijn langh gedruckt gheweeſt, inden name vanden Coninck doch teghens ſijnen wil, ende tot ſijn ſchade. Laet ons hem nu eenen Dienſt doen inder daet, in deſer tijt van ſijne grootſte afflictie, daer in God hem wonderlijcken vercloeckt ende vermogent ghemaeckt heeft om uyt te ſtaen, ende te verdraghen, ende ſal ſonder twyfel ter rechter tijt, hem ons weder geven ende ons tot onſe bekende Wetten ende Vryheyt brenghen. Siet op den Prince van Wales, ſtaende
Erffgenaem vande drie Croonen ende Generaliſſimo onder ſijnen Conincklijcken Vader, over alle Machten te Water ende te Landt. Siet op den Hertoch van Yorck Grooten Admirael van Englandt, zijnde Princen van ſo groote hope en verwachtinge, dat de Wereelt dier ghelijcke niet en heeft, ghekomen van het grootſte Bloet in 't Chriſtenri • ck, geallieert ende bevrundet met al de andre Buyten-Landtſche Potentaten, gheroepen tot de Scotſche Natie ende het meeſte deel van d'onſe, om het hare wederom te kryghen die daer geene handt gehadt hebben inde ellenden des Coninckrijcks, ende conſidereert by U ſelven met wat Godlijcke oft Menſchen Wet, Sy uyt hare gherechtighe Poſſeſſie konnen geſtooten werden in Ballingſchap, om daer in te leven als oft het ware vande aelmoeſſen van vremde. Comt ende voecht U tot ons, ende U en ſal niets ontbreken: Wy hebben goede Schepen, goede Herten, goede Handen, ende dat boven allen weert is, God ende het Recht aen onſe zyde. Ende den Almachtighen Door-ſoecker van alle Herten wil ons ſo voorſpoedighen in onſe Voor-nemigen, ghelijck wy voor-hebben de bevoorderinghe van ſijn Glorie tot het beſtendighen vande ware Proteſtante Religie, naer ſijn heyligh Woort, de Eere, Vryheyt ende goet Recht van Sijne Majeſteyt tot de continuatie, vande Privilegien van 't Parlament ende vande Liberteyt vanden Orderdaen door eene egale oft gemeyne wel-gegronded Vrede.

div.head: A Declaration of the Officers and Company of Seamen aboard his Majeſties Ships the Conſtant Reformation, the Convertine, the Swallow, the Antelope, the Satisfaction, the Hynd, the Roebuck, the Creſcent, the Pellican, the Blackmore Lady; lately reſcued for his Majeſties ſervice; with an Invitacion to the rest of the fleet, and their Brethren on land to joyne with them in their juſt undertakings.
div.p:
WEE have long expected with great impatience, an happy end of our waſting diviſions by meanes of a perſonall Treaty, ſo often preſſed by our Brethren of Scotland, and earneſtly deſired by the Generalitie of the Kingdome, as appeareth by the late ſeverall Petitions of the reſpective Counties to that purpoſe. But wee find by ſad experience that the Independent partie, in ſteed of applying themſelves to the ſettlement and compoſure of differences, according to their faith publiquely given to the whole Kingdome (But moſt ſhamefully violated in their propoſalls of the Army) have ſeized into their handes, and guarriſoned all the ſtrong places of the Kingdom, overrunning, diſarming, and plundering the Country, as if it were a conquered Nation. And all this for no other cauſe, But that they, in an humble way had manifeſted their deſire of peace, and to have an end of ſo heavy preſſures, which lay uppon them, by the arbitrary power of Committees, and the uniuſt continuation of the Exciſe and Land-taxes, after the utter defeat of the Kings partie; from whoſe fines and Compoſitions they drew mony enough to have ſatisfied moſt part of the debts of the Kingdom. And Seing likewiſe, that the Power and Affaires of the navy, were put into ſuch handes, as were not onely enemyes to the King and Kingedome, but euen to Monarchy it ſelfe, that the ſtyle of Commiſſions at ſea were latly altered, leauing out the Kinges name, and mentioning onely the Parliament and Army, which wee underſtood to bee a diſinheriſon of his Majeſty and his childeren, that wee had no ſettled forme of divine worſhipp, no Communions, little or no preaching on board, but by illiterate and mechanique perſons, that there was a deſigne of introducing land fouldiers into every ſhip to maſter and overawe the ſea men, things ſo contrary to the antient Cuſtomes and Orders of the Sea, that wee thought our ſelves bound in conſcience to doe ſomething for the recovery of our owne right, the reeſtabliſhment
of religion according to the word of God, and the covenant ſolemly taken, the honor, preſervation, and freedome of his Majeſty, the Priviledge of Parliament, and the Liberty of the Subject, and not bee made any longer the unhappy Inſtruments of the miſery of King and Kingedome, at which time God put it into our mindes, and incouraged our hearts, and ſtrengthned our handes, to remove Collonel Rainsborough from the command of the fleete, a man of moſt deſtructive Principles both in Religion and Policie, and a known enemy to the peace and ancient goverment of this Kingedome which we have ſworne to uphold and mantayne with our lives and fortunes, Deſyreinge all honeſt ſeamen not to be deluded any longer with wordes, but one and all, to joyne with us, and to put to their handes to ſo honeſt a worke, the glory whereof (next under God) will bee imputed to them, and the reward no queſtion will bee Proportionable, both in this world, and the world to come. Wee have bin longe preſſed in the Kinges name, though againſt his will and intereſt, let us now doe him ſome reall ſervice in this tyme of his greate affliction, which God hath wonderfully enabled him to beare, and will doubtleſſe in his good tyme reſtore him to us, and us to our knowne lawes and libertyes. Looke upon the Prince of Wales heir apparent of the three crownes, and Generaliſſimo under his Royall father of all forces by ſea and land. Looke upon the Duke of Yorke Lord high Admirall of England, Princes of ſo much hope and forwardnes, as the world hath not the like, extracted from the higheſt blood in Chriſtendome, allied to, and befreinded by all forraigne Potentates, invited by the Scottiſh Nation, and by the beſt part of ours to the recoveringe of their owne, who have had no hand in the miſeryes of this Kingedome, and conſider with your ſelves by what law of God or man they can bee thruſt out of their juſt Poſſeſſions into exile, there to live, as it were, upon the almes of ſtrangers Come in and joyne with us, and you ſhall want nothing: wee have good ſhippes, good heartes, good handes, and which is worth all, God, and the law on our ſyde. And the Almighty ſearcher of all hearts ſo proſper us in our undertakings as wee Intend the advancement of his glory in the ſetlement of the true Proteſtant religion according to his holy word, the honour freedome and juſt rightes of his Majeſty, the confirmation of the Priviledges of Parliament, and of the liberty of the ſubject, by an equall and wel grounded Peace.
